message_text: I have mixed feelings. Like the Mavs really started to turn it around when they had at least two of Luka, Dinwiddie, Brunson on the floor. Brunson honestly plays like a mini Luka.  Both are methodical drivers who use shiftiness and strength to get to their spots and score/pass. Dinwiddie on the other hand brings another element. He makes really quick decisions, whether is a quick drive after a catch on the weak side, quick swing pass, or burst out of the triple threat. It‚Äôs nice to have that dynamic next to the deliberate and methodical Luka. Plus the second year after the ACL injury is when guys usually start to look like themselves again. I think the biggest weakness is the second unit right now. There is talk of Wood coming of the bench to start, and that might be enough to boost them, especially with the return of THJ. But I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if another move was made to get another piece
context_prev: 334011|me|And idk how Gobert is gonna be on offense cause kat can shoot but Gobert just kinda sits there and Minnesota is stagnant a lot || 334124|me|What you been up to other then work?
context_next: 334094|them|With young guys, people talk about trying to build a contender while they are still on their rookie contract, but no one wins until they are 27. The guys that do tend to be in really good situations, like Magic with Kareem. As for their offense, yeah it will be interesting. Minnesota made their offense work last year with Vanderbilt lurking in the dunker spot a lot. Gobert can do a bit more. He‚Äôs really good at turning your weak side shooters into real threats with his off ball screening. The wolves also haven‚Äôt had a real downhill roll man. KAT likes to pop or post up more. Russel and Edwards will have plenty of lob opportunities. But spacing will be off. If I play small, and KAT wants to post me up, I can swarm him, and be pretty effective. KAT doesn‚Äôt deal with doubles well, and tends to turn it over || 333472|them|I‚Äôm in India right now with family for the summer. Spent these last few days in Delhi, and am going back to Hyderabad soon

message_text: So personally I think PER is outdated. It‚Äôs not really a good indicator of what the league values right now. Teams value floor spacing, shot creation, and defense. PER doesn‚Äôt adequately measure any of those. I also use player tracking data, instead of just box score data. This makes a big difference, especially when it comes to perimeter defense. Traditional stats primarily rely on steal/block numbers. I look at things like how many times you actually contest a shot, how the opponent gets worse when you match up with them, etc.
context_prev: 544234|me|Oh wow that‚Äôs really interesting, don‚Äôt they already have PeR and stuff like that || 544036|me|How‚Äôs what you do different
context_next: 544147|them|For offense, in addition to points, I look at how many of your field goals were assisted, how valuable those assists were, different types of offensive rebounds, time of possession, etc || 543945|them|In general I use a lot more data that is based on actual player tracking, as appears to approximations based on box score
